elements.content: A 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected zfy network, based on a trigonal bipyramid Zn2(CO2)2(NN) unit, with excellent chemical and thermal stability has been synthesized, which shows triple aromatic walls and nanoscale one-dimensional square channels.
elements.clean_text: A 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected zfy network, based on a trigonal bipyramid Zn2(CO2)2(NN) unit, with excellent chemical and thermal stability has been synthesized, which shows triple aromatic walls and nanoscale one-dimensional square channels.

elements.content: A 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected zfy network, based on a trigonal bipyramid Zn2(CO2)2(NN) unit, with excellent chemical and thermal stability has been synthesized, which shows triple aromatic walls and nanoscale one-dimensional square channels.
elements.clean_text: A 3-fold interpenetrated uninodal 5-connected zfy network, based on a trigonal bipyramid Zn2(CO2)2(NN) unit, with excellent chemical and thermal stability has been synthesized, which shows triple aromatic walls and nanoscale one-dimensional square channels.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous interest in recent years owing to their potential applications in many areas, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensors, and drug delivery. For the practical application of MOFs in these regions, advantage factors, such as high surface areas, accessible permanent porosities, tunable structures, and high chemical and/or thermal stability, are very essential to be considered. The current studies show that the employment of various polynuclear metallic units as secondary building units (SBUs) to link numerous organic linkers is a promising synthetic strategy for MOFs. The simple connection between inorganic SBUs and organic linkers can produce MOFs with desirable topologies and properties. Up to date, a variety of uniform and uninodal networks have been realized, of which majorities are based on 3-, 4-, and 6-connected nodes. Some 8-, 9-, and even highly connected network structures had also been synthesized in recent years. Surprisingly, examples of 5-connected uniform or uninodal networks are extremely scarce, and their structural characteristics, properties, and the relationship are still a mystery.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous interest in recent years owing to their potential applications in many areas, such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensors, and drug delivery. For the practical application of MOFs in these regions, advantage factors, such as high surface areas, accessible permanent porosities, tunable structures, and high chemical and/or thermal stability, are very essential to be considered. The current studies show that the employment of various polynuclear metallic units as secondary building units (SBUs) to link numerous organic linkers is a promising synthetic strategy for MOFs. The simple connection between inorganic SBUs and organic linkers can produce MOFs with desirable topologies and properties. Up to date, a variety of uniform and uninodal networks have been realized, of which majorities are based on 3-, 4-, and 6-connected nodes. Some 8-, 9-, and even highly connected network structures had also been synthesized in recent years. Surprisingly, examples of 5-connected uniform or uninodal networks are extremely scarce, and their structural characteristics, properties, and the relationship are still a mystery.

elements.content: On the other hand, it is well-known that the network topologies of MOFs can also be effectively controlled and modulated by modifying the linking nature of organic ligands. Aromatic carboxylates are widely employed because they have a rigid organic skeleton and strong coordination ability toward many metals. Recent studies show that the employment of mixed ligands was a very effective approach to build novel MOFs. These MOFs not only have various new topological networks but also possess stable porous frameworks. Inspired by the aforementioned consideration, our current synthetic strategy is to construct porous MOFs by employing two rigid ligands, biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (bpdc) and 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethyl-4,4′-bipyrazole (Me4bpz). It is already known that Me4bpz can act as a neutral bridging ligand by using both pyrazole ends to ligate a pair of metal ions and serve as mono- or divalent anionic ligands to bridge more metal ions. Furthermore, the presence of methyl groups on the Me4bpz ligand may be beneficial to tune the size and surface property of the pore. Therefore, these unique peculiarities of Me4bpz can be expected to build unusual MOFs with different organic ligands. Herein, we present a new three-dimensional (3D) porous MOF, [Zn4(HMe4bpz)2(bpdc)3] n (1), based on mixed bpdc and Me4bpz ligands. Remarkably, it shows high thermal and chemical stability and possesses an unusual five-connected zfy topology with the trigonal bipyramid binuclear zinc units as the 5-connected nodes.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, it is well-known that the network topologies of MOFs can also be effectively controlled and modulated by modifying the linking nature of organic ligands. Aromatic carboxylates are widely employed because they have a rigid organic skeleton and strong coordination ability toward many metals. Recent studies show that the employment of mixed ligands was a very effective approach to build novel MOFs. These MOFs not only have various new topological networks but also possess stable porous frameworks. Inspired by the aforementioned consideration, our current synthetic strategy is to construct porous MOFs by employing two rigid ligands, biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (bpdc) and 3,3',5,5'-tetramethyl-4,4'-bipyrazole (Me4bpz). It is already known that Me4bpz can act as a neutral bridging ligand by using both pyrazole ends to ligate a pair of metal ions and serve as mono- or divalent anionic ligands to bridge more metal ions. Furthermore, the presence of methyl groups on the Me4bpz ligand may be beneficial to tune the size and surface property of the pore. Therefore, these unique peculiarities of Me4bpz can be expected to build unusual MOFs with different organic ligands. Herein, we present a new three-dimensional (3D) porous MOF, [Zn4(HMe4bpz)2(bpdc)3] n  (1), based on mixed bpdc and Me4bpz ligands. Remarkably, it shows high thermal and chemical stability and possesses an unusual five-connected zfy topology with the trigonal bipyramid binuclear zinc units as the 5-connected nodes.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of ZnSO4·7H2O with H2Me4bpz and H2bpdc in DMF–MeOH solvent at 120 °C for 3 days afforded light-yellow block crystals of 1. The structure of 1 was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (Figure b), elemental analysis, and IR spectrum (Figure S1, see the ). The phase purity of the bulk product was further supported by the powder X-ray diffraction (Figure b). Compound 1 is insoluble in water and common organic solvents.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of ZnSO4⋅7H2O with H2Me4bpz and H2bpdc in DMF-MeOH solvent at 120 °C for 3 days afforded light-yellow block crystals of 1. The structure of 1 was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (Figure b), elemental analysis, and IR spectrum (Figure S1, see the ). The phase purity of the bulk product was further supported by the powder X-ray diffraction (Figure b). Compound 1 is insoluble in water and common organic solvents.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that compound 1 crystallized in the tetragonal space group I41/a. There are two independent zinc(II) ions, one HMe4bpz, and one and a half of bpdc ligands in the asymmetric unit. One bpdc ligand lies on a crystallographic inversion center (denoted as bpdc-1), and another bpdc ligand (denoted as bpdc-2) is in the general position. As shown in Figure a, the deprotonated bpdc-1 and bpdc-2 ligands exhibit μ2-η1-η0-η1-η0 and μ4-η1-η1-η1-η1 coordination modes, respectively. The HMe4bpz ligand is monodeprotonated and adopts a μ3-η1-η1-η1 bridging mode. One prominent structural feature of 1 is the presence of an unusual trigonal bipyramid binuclear Zn(II) unit (Zn2(CO2)2(NN), Zn2–SBU). In this Zn2–SBU, two Zn(II) ions are bridged by a pair of carboxylate groups from two bpdc-2 ligands and one deprotonated pyrazole group on the equatorial plane with the Zn···Zn distance of 3.240 Å. Two axial positions of the Zn2–SBU are completed by one carboxylate group from the bpdc-1 ligand, and one nondeprotonated pyrazole group. Each Zn(II) ions in the Zn2–SBU has common tetrahedral geometry. All Zn–O and Zn–N bond distances fall in the normal range of 1.894(3)–1.999(4) Å. To the best of our knowledge, no such [Zn2(CO2)2(NN)] SBU has been reported in the literature. The Zn2–SBU further connects to five neighboring ones through one bpdc-1, two bpdc-2, and two HMe4bpz ligands, forming a 3D framework. From the viewpoints of topology, 1 features a uninodal 5-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of 43.54.63 (Figure c and Figure S9 of the ), when the Zn2–SBUs are considered as 5-connected nodes and the bpdc/HMe4bpz ligands act as linkers. Such network had been identified as zfy net according to the RCSR symbol, which is previously unreported in MOFs. Thus, 1 represents the first example of this rare uninodal 5-connected network.
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that compound 1 crystallized in the tetragonal space group I41/a. There are two independent zinc(II) ions, one HMe4bpz, and one and a half of bpdc ligands in the asymmetric unit. One bpdc ligand lies on a crystallographic inversion center (denoted as bpdc-1), and another bpdc ligand (denoted as bpdc-2) is in the general position. As shown in Figure a, the deprotonated bpdc-1 and bpdc-2 ligands exhibit μ2-η1-η0-η1-η0 and μ4-η1-η1-η1-η1 coordination modes, respectively. The HMe4bpz ligand is monodeprotonated and adopts a μ3-η1-η1-η1 bridging mode. One prominent structural feature of 1 is the presence of an unusual trigonal bipyramid binuclear Zn(II) unit (Zn2(CO2)2(NN), Zn2-SBU). In this Zn2-SBU, two Zn(II) ions are bridged by a pair of carboxylate groups from two bpdc-2 ligands and one deprotonated pyrazole group on the equatorial plane with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 3.240 Å. Two axial positions of the Zn2-SBU are completed by one carboxylate group from the bpdc-1 ligand, and one nondeprotonated pyrazole group. Each Zn(II) ions in the Zn2-SBU has common tetrahedral geometry. All Zn-O and Zn-N bond distances fall in the normal range of 1.894(3)-1.999(4) Å. To the best of our knowledge, no such [Zn2(CO2)2(NN)] SBU has been reported in the literature. The Zn2-SBU further connects to five neighboring ones through one bpdc-1, two bpdc-2, and two HMe4bpz ligands, forming a 3D framework. From the viewpoints of topology, 1 features a uninodal 5-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of 43.54.63 (Figure c and Figure S9 of the ), when the Zn2-SBUs are considered as 5-connected nodes and the bpdc/HMe4bpz ligands act as linkers. Such network had been identified as zfy net according to the RCSR symbol, which is previously unreported in MOFs. Thus, 1 represents the first example of this rare uninodal 5-connected network.

elements.content: a. View of the structure of Zn2–SBU in 1 with 30% thermal ellipsoids. H atoms bonded to carbon atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetric code: (a) 0.25 + y, 0.25 – x, −0.75 + z, (b) 0.75 – y, −0.25 + x, 1.75 – z, and (c) 0.5 – x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 – z. (b) Packing diagram of 1 shows 3-fold interpenetrated frameworks with one-dimensional (1D) square channels along the c axis. (c) The 5-connected zfy topology with the trigonal bipyramid Zn2–SBU as the 5-connected node; only one subnet is shown for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  a. View of the structure of Zn2-SBU in 1 with 30% thermal ellipsoids. H atoms bonded to carbon atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetric code: (a) 0.25 + y, 0.25 - x, -0.75 + z, (b) 0.75 - y, -0.25 + x, 1.75 - z, and (c) 0.5 - x, 0.5 - y, -0.5 - z. (b) Packing diagram of 1 shows 3-fold interpenetrated frameworks with one-dimensional (1D) square channels along the c axis. (c) The 5-connected zfy topology with the trigonal bipyramid Zn2-SBU as the 5-connected node; only one subnet is shown for clarity.

elements.content: (a) TGA curve of 1. (b) PXRD patterns of 1: (I) simulated, (II) as-synthesized, (III) heated at 300 °C for 30 min in air, (IV) heated at 400 °C in air, (V) reflux in water at 80 °C for one hour, hydrothermal treated, (VI) in water at 170 °C for 24 h, and solvothermal, (VII) in ethanol at 130 °C for 72 h, and (VIII) in DMF at 170 °C for 72 h.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) TGA curve of 1. (b) PXRD patterns of 1: (I) simulated, (II) as-synthesized, (III) heated at 300 °C for 30 min in air, (IV) heated at 400 °C in air, (V) reflux in water at 80 °C for one hour, hydrothermal treated, (VI) in water at 170 °C for 24 h, and solvothermal, (VII) in ethanol at 130 °C for 72 h, and (VIII) in DMF at 170 °C for 72 h.

elements.content: The empty spaces of such 3D framework are filled by the other two identical frameworks, leading to a 3-fold interpenetrated network with 1D square channels about 10.0 × 10.0 Å (by considering the van der Waals radius) along the c axis (Figure b). Significantly, there are no solvent molecules residing in the channels, representing a rare guest-free MOF material. The methyl groups in 1 also define a hydrophobic channel along the c axis; however, the small diameter of this channel implies that it is inaccessible for guest molecules. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 5570.3 Å3 per unit cell, which is 34.2% of the crystal volume.
elements.clean_text: The empty spaces of such 3D framework are filled by the other two identical frameworks, leading to a 3-fold interpenetrated network with 1D square channels about 10.0 × 10.0 Å (by considering the van der Waals radius) along the c axis (Figure b). Significantly, there are no solvent molecules residing in the channels, representing a rare guest-free MOF material. The methyl groups in 1 also define a hydrophobic channel along the c axis; however, the small diameter of this channel implies that it is inaccessible for guest molecules. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 5570.3 Å3 per unit cell, which is 34.2% of the crystal volume.

elements.content: The most striking feature of 1 is the existence of triple aromatic walls consisted of the biphenyl groups of bpdc-1 (in the middle) and bpdc-2 (in the two sides) from three subnets. There are intersubnet π···π stacking interactions (Figure S6 of the ) within these biphenyl groups mentioned above, as well as intersubnet hydrogen bonds (N4–H4···O6, 2.755 Å), intrasubnet C–H···π interactions involving the methyl groups as H-donors, and carboxylate and pyrazole groups as H-acceptors (Table S3, and Figures S7, S8 of the ). The presence of triple aromatic walls and a large amount of inter- and intra-subnets supramolecular interactions can greatly increase the stability of the whole framework.
elements.clean_text: The most striking feature of 1 is the existence of triple aromatic walls consisted of the biphenyl groups of bpdc-1 (in the middle) and bpdc-2 (in the two sides) from three subnets. There are intersubnet π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions (Figure S6 of the ) within these biphenyl groups mentioned above, as well as intersubnet hydrogen bonds (N4-H4⋅⋅⋅O6, 2.755 Å), intrasubnet C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions involving the methyl groups as H-donors, and carboxylate and pyrazole groups as H-acceptors (Table S3, and Figures S7, S8 of the ). The presence of triple aromatic walls and a large amount of inter- and intra-subnets supramolecular interactions can greatly increase the stability of the whole framework.

elements.content: The chemical and thermal stability of 1 has been investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern. The TGA curve suggests that 1 can stay stable at high temperatures up to 465 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The PXRD analysis show that 1 retains its crystallinity after being heated up to 400 °C in air or kept at 300 °C for 30 min in air. Our further tests reveal that 1 can also retain its crystallinity by three processing modes as follows: (1) suspending the crystal samples of 1 in water with stirring at 80 °C for one hour, (2) hydrothermal treatment in water at 170 °C for 24 h, and (3) solvothermal treatment in dimethyl formamide (DMF) at 170 °C for 72 h or in ethanol at 130 °C for 72 h. The TGA and PXRD analysis shows that compound 1 has excellent thermal stability in the class of bivalent M(II)-based MOFs.
elements.clean_text: The chemical and thermal stability of 1 has been investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern. The TGA curve suggests that 1 can stay stable at high temperatures up to 465 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The PXRD analysis show that 1 retains its crystallinity after being heated up to 400 °C in air or kept at 300 °C for 30 min in air. Our further tests reveal that 1 can also retain its crystallinity by three processing modes as follows: (1) suspending the crystal samples of 1 in water with stirring at 80 °C for one hour, (2) hydrothermal treatment in water at 170 °C for 24 h, and (3) solvothermal treatment in dimethyl formamide (DMF) at 170 °C for 72 h or in ethanol at 130 °C for 72 h. The TGA and PXRD analysis shows that compound 1 has excellent thermal stability in the class of bivalent M(II)-based MOFs.

elements.content: Although compound 1 exhibits open channels and porosity, as suggested by structural analysis, the nitrogen sorption studies at liquid nitrogen temperature performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer, do not show obvious gas sorption. The H2 gas adsorption measurement of 1 at 77 K was further investigated, which confirms the microporosity of 1. A significant increase in the amount of H2 gas adsorbed by 1 (69 cm3 g–1 STP at 1 bar) was observed as with an increase in the H2 pressure (Figure ), indicating the diffusion of H2 molecules into the channels.
elements.clean_text: Although compound 1 exhibits open channels and porosity, as suggested by structural analysis, the nitrogen sorption studies at liquid nitrogen temperature performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer, do not show obvious gas sorption. The H2 gas adsorption measurement of 1 at 77 K was further investigated, which confirms the microporosity of 1. A significant increase in the amount of H2 gas adsorbed by 1 (69 cm3 g-1 STP at 1 bar) was observed as with an increase in the H2 pressure (Figure ), indicating the diffusion of H2 molecules into the channels.

elements.content: N2 and H2 adsorption isotherm of 1 measured at 77 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  N2 and H2 adsorption isotherm of 1 measured at 77 K.

elements.content: The photoluminescence (PL) spectrum of 1 displays two emission peak bands at 475 and 560 nm upon excitation at 350 nm at room temperature (Figure S4 of the ). The fluorescence of 1 is completely different from that of the ligands, which give a strong fluorescence peak at 405 nm upon excitation at 340 nm for H2pbdc and 440 nm upon excitation at 380 nm for H2Me4bpz, respectively (Figure S5 of the ). The emission peak at 560 nm is considered to be attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) from O–Zn or N–Zn bonds, which are often observed from 500 to 530 nm. The emission peaks at 475 nm should come from the HMe4bpz ligand centered π* → π transition, and this observed red-shift is likely due to the strong electronic coupling between the neighboring ligands through the Zn(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: The photoluminescence (PL) spectrum of 1 displays two emission peak bands at 475 and 560 nm upon excitation at 350 nm at room temperature (Figure S4 of the ). The fluorescence of 1 is completely different from that of the ligands, which give a strong fluorescence peak at 405 nm upon excitation at 340 nm for H2pbdc and 440 nm upon excitation at 380 nm for H2Me4bpz, respectively (Figure S5 of the ). The emission peak at 560 nm is considered to be attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) from O-Zn or N-Zn bonds, which are often observed from 500 to 530 nm. The emission peaks at 475 nm should come from the HMe4bpz ligand centered π* → π transition, and this observed red-shift is likely due to the strong electronic coupling between the neighboring ligands through the Zn(II) ions.

elements.content: In summary, we have constructed a highly chemical and thermal stable porous MOF with triple aromatic walls through the combination of rigid dicarboxylate and bipyrazole. Remarkably, it is based on an unusual trigonal bipyramid binuclear zinc(II) unit and represents the first example of MOF with uninodal 5-connected zfy topology.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have constructed a highly chemical and thermal stable porous MOF with triple aromatic walls through the combination of rigid dicarboxylate and bipyrazole. Remarkably, it is based on an unusual trigonal bipyramid binuclear zinc(II) unit and represents the first example of MOF with uninodal 5-connected zfy topology.

elements.content:
X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, material and instruments, Tables S1–S3, and Figures S1–S9 of compound 1. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

A mixture of H2Me4bpz (0.0190 g, 0.10 mmol), H2bpdc (0.0242 g, 0.10 mmol) and ZnSO4·7H2O (0.0287 g, 0.10 mmol) in 4 mL DMF and 1 mL methanol was heated in a 23 mL Teflon reactor at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature over a period of 20 h, light-yellow block crystals of 1 in yield of 54% (0.0370 g) were obtained. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C31H25N4O6Zn2: C, 54.73; H, 3.70; N, 8.24. Found: C, 54.20; H, 4.06; N, 8.29. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3468s, 2865w, 1614s, 1589m, 1544s, 1498m, 1420s, 1400s, 1384s, 1178m, 1045m, 1007m, 842m, 768s, 682m, 477m.

A mixture of H2Me4bpz (0.0190 g, 0.10 mmol), H2bpdc (0.0242 g, 0.10 mmol) and ZnSO4⋅7H2O (0.0287 g, 0.10 mmol) in 4 mL DMF and 1 mL methanol was heated in a 23 mL Teflon reactor at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature over a period of 20 h, light-yellow block crystals of 1 in yield of 54% (0.0370 g) were obtained. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C31H25N4O6Zn2: C, 54.73; H, 3.70; N, 8.24. Found: C, 54.20; H, 4.06; N, 8.29. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3468s, 2865w, 1614s, 1589m, 1544s, 1498m, 1420s, 1400s, 1384s, 1178m, 1045m, 1007m, 842m, 768s, 682m, 477m.

elements.content: Crystal data for 1: C31H25N4O6Zn2, tetragonal, space group I41/a, M r = 680.29, a = 43.719(6) Å, c = 8.5159(17) Å, V = 16277(5) Å3, Z = 16, D c = 1.110 g3 cm–3, F(000) = 5552, and μ = 1.216 mm–1. T = 293(2) K. Data collections of 1 were performed with Mo K α radiation (λ = 0.71073Å) on a Rigaku R axis RAPID diffractometer. A total of 26490 reflections were collected in the range of 3.07 < 2θ < 27.47°, of which 8313 (R int = 0.0962) were independent. Final R 1 = 0.0613 for 4961 reflections with I > 4σ(I), ωR 2 = 0.1269, and GOF = 1.054 for all 8313 data. The structure was solved by direct methods and expanded using Fourier techniques. Nonhydrogen atoms are refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically. All calculations were performed using SHELXS97 and SHELXL97 programs.

T = 293(2) K. Data collections of 1 were performed with Mo K α radiation (λ = 0.71073Å) on a Rigaku R axis RAPID diffractometer. A total of 26490 reflections were collected in the range of 3.07 < 2θ < 27.47°, of which 8313 (R int = 0.0962) were independent. Final R 1 = 0.0613 for 4961 reflections with I > 4σ(I), ωR 2 = 0.1269, and GOF = 1.054 for all 8313 data. The structure was solved by direct methods and expanded using Fourier techniques. Nonhydrogen atoms are refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically. All calculations were performed using SHELXS97 and SHELXL97 programs.

cln_elements.content:
The empty spaces of such 3D framework are filled by the other two identical frameworks, leading to a 3-fold interpenetrated network with 1D square channels about 10.0 × 10.0 Å (by considering the van der Waals radius) along the c axis (Figure b). Significantly, there are no solvent molecules residing in the channels, representing a rare guest-free MOF material. The methyl groups in 1 also define a hydrophobic channel along the c axis; however, the small diameter of this channel implies that it is inaccessible for guest molecules. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 5570.3 Å3 per unit cell, which is 34.2% of the crystal volume.

The chemical and thermal stability of 1 has been investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern. The TGA curve suggests that 1 can stay stable at high temperatures up to 465 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The PXRD analysis show that 1 retains its crystallinity after being heated up to 400 °C in air or kept at 300 °C for 30 min in air. Our further tests reveal that 1 can also retain its crystallinity by three processing modes as follows: (1) suspending the crystal samples of 1 in water with stirring at 80 °C for one hour, (2) hydrothermal treatment in water at 170 °C for 24 h, and (3) solvothermal treatment in dimethyl formamide (DMF) at 170 °C for 72 h or in ethanol at 130 °C for 72 h. The TGA and PXRD analysis shows that compound 1 has excellent thermal stability in the class of bivalent M(II)-based MOFs.

Although compound 1 exhibits open channels and porosity, as suggested by structural analysis, the nitrogen sorption studies at liquid nitrogen temperature performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer, do not show obvious gas sorption. The H2 gas adsorption measurement of 1 at 77 K was further investigated, which confirms the microporosity of 1. A significant increase in the amount of H2 gas adsorbed by 1 (69 cm3 g–1 STP at 1 bar) was observed as with an increase in the H2 pressure (Figure ), indicating the diffusion of H2 molecules into the channels.

Crystal data for 1: C31H25N4O6Zn2, tetragonal, space group I41/a, M r = 680.29, a = 43.719(6) Å, c = 8.5159(17) Å, V = 16277(5) Å3, Z = 16, D c = 1.110 g3 cm–3, F(000) = 5552, and μ = 1.216 mm–1. T = 293(2) K. Data collections of 1 were performed with Mo K α radiation (λ = 0.71073Å) on a Rigaku R axis RAPID diffractometer. A total of 26490 reflections were collected in the range of 3.07 < 2θ < 27.47°, of which 8313 (R int = 0.0962) were independent. Final R 1 = 0.0613 for 4961 reflections with I > 4σ(I), ωR 2 = 0.1269, and GOF = 1.054 for all 8313 data. The structure was solved by direct methods and expanded using Fourier techniques. Nonhydrogen atoms are refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically. All calculations were performed using SHELXS97 and SHELXL97 programs.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The empty spaces of such 3D framework are filled by the other two identical frameworks, leading to a 3-fold interpenetrated network with 1D square channels about 10.0 × 10.0 Å (by considering the van der Waals radius) along the c axis (Figure b). Significantly, there are no solvent molecules residing in the channels, representing a rare guest-free MOF material. The methyl groups in 1 also define a hydrophobic channel along the c axis; however, the small diameter of this channel implies that it is inaccessible for guest molecules. PLATON calculations indicate that the effective volume is 5570.3 Å3 per unit cell, which is 34.2% of the crystal volume.

The chemical and thermal stability of 1 has been investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern. The TGA curve suggests that 1 can stay stable at high temperatures up to 465 °C under a N2 atmosphere. The PXRD analysis show that 1 retains its crystallinity after being heated up to 400 °C in air or kept at 300 °C for 30 min in air. Our further tests reveal that 1 can also retain its crystallinity by three processing modes as follows: (1) suspending the crystal samples of 1 in water with stirring at 80 °C for one hour, (2) hydrothermal treatment in water at 170 °C for 24 h, and (3) solvothermal treatment in dimethyl formamide (DMF) at 170 °C for 72 h or in ethanol at 130 °C for 72 h. The TGA and PXRD analysis shows that compound 1 has excellent thermal stability in the class of bivalent M(II)-based MOFs.

Although compound 1 exhibits open channels and porosity, as suggested by structural analysis, the nitrogen sorption studies at liquid nitrogen temperature performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer, do not show obvious gas sorption. The H2 gas adsorption measurement of 1 at 77 K was further investigated, which confirms the microporosity of 1. A significant increase in the amount of H2 gas adsorbed by 1 (69 cm3 g-1 STP at 1 bar) was observed as with an increase in the H2 pressure (Figure ), indicating the diffusion of H2 molecules into the channels.

Crystal data for 1: C31H25N4O6Zn2, tetragonal, space group I41/a, M r = 680.29, a = 43.719(6) Å, c = 8.5159(17) Å, V = 16277(5) Å3, Z = 16, D c = 1.110 g3 cm-3, F(000) = 5552, and μ = 1.216 mm-1. T = 293(2) K. Data collections of 1 were performed with Mo K α radiation (λ = 0.71073Å) on a Rigaku R axis RAPID diffractometer. A total of 26490 reflections were collected in the range of 3.07 < 2θ < 27.47°, of which 8313 (R int = 0.0962) were independent. Final R 1 = 0.0613 for 4961 reflections with I > 4σ(I), ωR 2 = 0.1269, and GOF = 1.054 for all 8313 data. The structure was solved by direct methods and expanded using Fourier techniques. Nonhydrogen atoms are refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically. All calculations were performed using SHELXS97 and SHELXL97 programs.

cln_elements.content: a. View of the structure of Zn2–SBU in 1 with 30% thermal ellipsoids. H atoms bonded to carbon atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetric code: (a) 0.25 + y, 0.25 – x, −0.75 + z, (b) 0.75 – y, −0.25 + x, 1.75 – z, and (c) 0.5 – x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 – z. (b) Packing diagram of 1 shows 3-fold interpenetrated frameworks with one-dimensional (1D) square channels along the c axis. (c) The 5-connected zfy topology with the trigonal bipyramid Zn2–SBU as the 5-connected node; only one subnet is shown for clarity.

metadata.title:
A Highly Chemical and Thermal Stable Porous Metal–Organic
Framework with Unusual 5‑Connected zfy Topology
